title: XuGong V1&2 Folding Landing Gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The stock landing gears are really short so I designed a longer foldable variant. To make locking easier without tools I've designed knobs for the nuts.

Parts needed:
4 pcs M3x10 screws
4 pcs M3 nuts (preferably 2 of those are NYLOC)
1 pcs 106mm M3 threaded rod
1 pcs 82mm M3 threaded rod

Instructions:

  1. Unmount the existing rubber legs on the bottom frame
  2. Unmount the screws where the undercarriage will be installed
  3. Install the front mount (widest) using two M3x10 screws
  4. Install M3 nut + Plastic knob + Plastic washer on the longer threaded rod
  5. Install front leg (widest) using the longer M3 threaded rod
  6. Install Plastic washer + Plastic knob + M3 nut on the end of the threaded rod
  7. Repeat step 3-6 for the rear part of the undercarriage

Fatshark & Skyzone Faceplate suitable* for all fatshark and skyzone goggles family.

(*) : Some models may require some cuts on the faceplate.

• Print 2 pieces (attfp.stl)
  • Bend each faceplate slowly and gently to have some curve
  • Slide each faceplate to goggles.
  • Use self adhesive sponge strips for the faceplates border.

For Skyzone single eyecup

  • Print skyzone parts
  • Bend each faceplate slowly and gently to have some curve
  • Slide each faceplate to goggles.
  • Use locktooth to lock pieces together.
  • Use self adhesive sponge strips for the faceplates border.

This is a simple two part compass for drawing circles, measuring, and navigating the open seas old timey pirate style. Parts:
  • 2 copies of the compass half
  • 2 thumscrews
  • 2 washers, 1 wingnut and bolt

• Download
  • Skeinforge
  • Print two copies (It should fit diagonally on the makerbot build surface)
  • Insert 1 thumbscrew in each end of the compass to hold a pencil, pen, dowel extension, etc.
  • Bolt together the two halves with a small thumbscrew or wingnut for easy adjustment. You may want to put a larger washer on the outside of the two parts if the plastic isn't stiff enough to hold a precise angle.

title: Laser Cut Transparent Clear Hotend 3.0mm Rev1.0

description.text:
Tried plenty of material for hotend. Like J-Head peek, nylon, PU carbon then to all aluminum . Finally tried something different and result is promising. Heating time is fast and extrusion is somewhere 20-30% more efficient. Initially with direct drive gear filament, extrusion speed is 160mm/sec in Marlin setting. Now just 120mm/sec and still tuning it out for best print out.

Tried pulling out the filament while it is still hot and notice that the filament end tip melt is shorter then the others hotend. The heat from the aluminum heater block does not really transfer up to the hotend body and the best of all.... it is transparent clear!

Tested printing with outer perimeter at 30, 40,50 & 70mm/sec and result shows that it could be push further. The faster it print, the filament extrusion flow is more smooth. E motor is somehow more powerful now and it need less tension for filament grip at the idler. I was printing with DIY ABS filament, diameter is 2.55 to 3.05mm. If uses better tolerance filament, result will be even more better. With hair spray and heatbed at 80°C, ABS stick very well too!

I will upload & share more video later. Keep tune in and visit our site http://www.3dprinter.my TQ!
https://youtu.be/0_KJU0Yzy9Q

**Updated Dual Extruder pics. This is more easy and simple way to venture into mutli-colour printing!

Laser cut with 5mm thick material. Wood, Acrylic, etc...

BOM:

  1. M3x20 - 4pcs
  2. M3x25 - 2pcs
  3. M3 Washer - 8pcs
  4. M3 Nut - 6pcs
  5. PTFE Tube OD4.5 x ID3.0mm
  6. PC04-M6 Pneumatic Connector (Drill ⌀4.0mm)
  7. Laser Cut Body x 1set
  8. SS M6xL15mm Threaded Rod (Drill ⌀4.5mm)
  9. PTFE Tape

remixed_from.author: cadsys
remixed_from.title: Indexable Bed Leveling Knobs for Rep 2x

description.text:
These press on top of the stock knob that came with my Makerbot Replicator 2. The internal bore allows for the knob to be installed at the end, so it's not a press fit from the top of the bore, only the last 2.5mm. The bottom of the bore has slight serrations, an attempt to match the knurl on the stock knob.

The outside of the knob is a tapered serration, 20 per revolution. Doing the math, one external tooth equals approx 0.001" (screw is M3x0.5mm, so 1 turn = 1/2mm or .020")

The taper is to allow for another knob piece to fit over it, with indexability. If anyone wants this, leave a comment and I'll add it.

Another neat feature is that these are pressed on, but also captured, so impossible for the knobs to get bumped and fall off.

Photos show (rev 1) of the design, which required press fit all the way into the bore. Rev 2 is improved, press fit only at the bottom of the bore.

Print 100% infill, .1mm layer, no raft, qty 3

Remove existing knobs from under build plate

Press the knobs into these printed parts

Reinstall knobs

title: iPad mini sunschade for DJI inspire or Phantom

description.text:
This sunshade slides together for easy transportation. The top part is too big for most 3D printers, I therefore provided two options;

  • You can print it in one piece if your printer allows it

or

  • I split it in two and provided a connection piece that can be glued to one side (to keep it compact) and then just slide the other side in. You can alse glue both sides in to it which will have the same result as printing it in one piece. You can also not glue it in at all and just slide both halves in when you assemble the shade.

In any case enjoy... :)

title: Printrbot LC fan shroud / air control

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTE: While this thing did seem to help cooling around bridging, it doesn't do much else except get in the way of the screwdown at XY home and disrupt your ability to view your print job. I'll leave this up as something others can work on, but I don't recommend people using this particular air shroud.  
...  
I noticed that the Printrbot LC cooling was less than optimal...it blows all over the place instead of directly on what needs to be cooled. This has an impact on bridging, stickiness, etc. This is a first attempt at directing the air flow directly at the just-extruded plastic, to see if it makes a difference. If you'd like to try the same, feel free to use this and please report your results back here.  
Sorry for the crappy photos.  
v2: Narrowed the bottom, but did not raise it. It didn't affect print quality. Note that in v1, if you are not clamping on a piece of glass on the default bed, you may hit the hand-adjust screw near home. Not ideal. Hopefully this is better. FWIW, I've had a hard time with the hand-adjust screws, so I'm turning them upside-down and just using a screwdriver.  
This is EXPERIMENTAL. I claim no responsibility for your printer, what you print, or any damage which may occur!

Improvements which could be made:
  • bring the bottom closer to the extruder
  • bring the bottom up closer, to be extra-safe that it doesn't impact the piece being printed
  • smooth the interior to reduce air drag
  • horizontally tighten the air direction (risk of blowing the first strands of bridging out of place?)
  • use a zap strap instead of garden wire! (I have no idea where my zap straps went)
    • This design does require bridging, so you'll want to be somewhat calibrated. If you think that you can't use this because you can't bridge, but this would likely help you do bridging, inquire with some kind soul to print you a copy of this :)

comments.text: So, a dozen print jobs later...
comments.author: SwimmingNaked

comments.text: Nice idea. How well does it work? Do you notice any difference?
comments.author: adampaterson

comments.text: I'm still testing...it may work too well, but all I have so far is anecdotal. I'm using PLA at 185 degrees, and it seems that multiple strands of bridges aren't sticking together very well. This might be a great thing if intentional, but if you want to create bridged solid items, maybe not. I may increase the temperature to 195 to see if it all handles well, the do a bridge torture test (something like 10cm).
comments.author: adampaterson

comments.text: Side note: Krazy glue works wonders if the strands of a bridge or a thin piece of a print aren't sticking together.

Many of you have some empty Nutella jars at home, so do I. And I thought: why not re-use the jar as a lantern one can use inside, outside and wherever you want to use it.

My design uses a 800g Nutella jar I bought in Germany. Not sure about the sizes in other countries. I designed my thing in Solidworks, if my design should not fit to other jars I can supply my original part files.

Will it fit on my Nutella jar? My nutella jar has an inner diameter of 73.75mm and an outer diameter of 79.6mm.

For the lighting I used four white LEDs, powered by a 9V block battery and operated by a simple switch. The circuit board is hold with a M8 screw to the print. The print has a thread for the screw.

The thing itself is printed with a MarkForged printer and is made out of Nylon.

To get some diffusivity in the jar I filled it with plastic wrap.

Have fun with your own lantern during these hot summer nights!
Looking forward to some re-prints!

UPDATE_17JUL: new and better pics from the jar as well as a new circuit.

The LEDs are just soldered to a circuit board. I used two 150 Ohms resistance, you can check the wirering in the pictures above. The board itself was screwed to the print with a M8 screw. You can find a stand-alone thing with an M8 thread in my profile, in case you want to check if your printer is able to print threads.

He published his thing while mine was printing.

title: Turnigy Fabrikator Flex Filament Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my very first Thing I ever created.
I made this guide for my Fabrikator to allow me to use flexible filament. I was inspired by a few other guides I found but they just didn't work for my printer, so I decided to try and design my own.
It's not perfect, but it works so far.
If you print and find issues, I'd love to hear your feedback so I can try to fix it.
Read instruction page for installation

V1 had a gap by the stepper drive wheel, I had a print fail due to the filament binding between the printed guide and the wheel. V1 has been deleted as it was obsolete and did not perform well.

V1.1 (Current version) added ridge on left side to try to fill the groove in the drive wheel.

Update 27 July 2015
I'm in the process of making and testing a 2 piece guide that will be able to be installed and removed without taking the front housing off.
Check back soon!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/a5X3WdM2YbM

I printed this in PLA with .1mm layer height, .8mm shell thickness, fill %10, supports around %15
I designed this to fit with the stock hot end, it sits in the curved cutout shown in picture. It should fit with a little movement but won't come out. The tab on the front is just to help slide it in place.
To install you must remove the front fan and black housing around the hot end, slide the guide in to place then replace the black housing and fan.

**I have found that even with the guide in place you have to print really slow with the Flexible Filament. I have been using a print speed of around 20-30MMs, head temp of 225, bed temp of 50.

I've uploaded the CURA 14.12 Printing Profile for the Turnigy Fabrikator that I have been using for actually printing flexible filament.
In Cura, go to File then Open Profile and navigate to the Profile you just downloaded. This will import all my settings. (use this as a baseline and adjust as needed)

comments.text:
• Any time I make an improvement, I delete the old version and upload the newest so, the newest will always be the only one available. This version has the update I described above "a little ridge on the left side curve to fill in the indention on the drive wheel". The only change I may make is to make this into a two piece guide to allow it to be installed without taking the fan shroud off.
  • I designed this for the full size Fabrikator not the Mini Fabrikator.
  • I do not own or know anyone locally that owns a Mini Fabrikator so I have no way of getting measurement to even begin to design a guide for it. Also most 3d printers that use the filament "feed tube" design have a hard time with flexible filament even with a guide, due to too much play inside the tube. Its like trying to push a wet spaghetti noodle through a drinking straw it just doesn't work well.

author: Despo

title: Laser Cut Transparent Clear Hotend 1.75mm Rev1.0

description.text:
Tried plenty of material for hotend. Like J-Head peek, nylon, PU carbon then to all aluminum . Finally tried something different and result is promising. Heating time is fast and extrusion is somewhere 20-30% more efficient. Initially with direct drive gear filament, extrusion speed is 160mm/sec in Marlin setting. Now just 120mm/sec and still tuning it out for best print out.

Tried pulling out the filament while it is still hot and notice that the filament end tip melt is shorter then the others hotend. The heat from the aluminum heater block does not really transfer up to the hotend body and the best of all.... it is transparent clear!

Tested printing with outer perimeter at 30, 40,50 & 70mm/sec and result shows that it could be push further. The faster it print, the filament extrusion flow is more smooth. E motor is somehow more powerful now and it need less tension for filament grip at the idler. I was printing with DIY ABS filament, diameter is 1.65 to 2.00mm. If uses better tolerance filament, result will be even more better. With hair spray and heatbed at 80°C, ABS stick very well too!

I will upload & share more video later. Keep tune in and visit our site http://www.3dprinter.my TQ!
https://youtu.be/0_KJU0Yzy9Q

Laser cut with 5mm thick material. Wood, Acrylic, etc...

BOM:

  1. M3x20 - 4pcs
  2. M3x25 - 2pcs
  3. M3 Washer - 8pcs
  4. M3 Nut - 6pcs
  5. PTFE Tube OD3.0 x ID2.0mm
  6. PC04-M6 Pneumatic Connector
  7. Laser Cut Body x 1set
  8. SS M6xL15mm Threaded Rod (Drill ⌀3.2mm)
  9. PTFE Tape

author: MJJ

description.text:
In Belgium (and other countries), the BOB keychain is a popular keychain as you can get it from the police after successfully completing a breathalyzer test (the chrome one in the picture is one I "won" yesterday, yay, let's copy it ...).   
Now here's some guerilla of the purest  essence: the BOB keychain design out on the internet so everyone can make their own non-drinking-and-driving prize! And you thought printable guns were a problem?  
From Wikipedia:  
"The Bob campaign aims to raise awareness of the dangers of driving while intoxicated; drivers with high blood alcohol content are at increased risk of car accidents, highway injuries and vehicular deaths. Alongside the general information that is offered during the campaign, there is an increased police surveillance, especially during the weeks running up to Christmas and New Year's Eve. But most of all, the campaign focuses on a designated driver approach.  
The Bob campaign originated in Belgium, in 1995, and the concept has been picked up in the Netherlands, France in 2006, Germany in 2007 and also Luxembourg, and Greece will follow, with every country adapting the formula to their audience.  
Some media have spread the rumor that the acronym is derived from the Dutch phrase "Bewust Onbeschonken Bestuurder" which translates to "Conscious Non-Drunk Driver" or 'deliberately sober driver'. Many people since then believe that this is true, but Bob is just a name chosen by the Belgian government."  
Thanks Marie for the inspiration!

description.text: Wrench used to aid assembly and disassembly of M1 Rifle. Measured the muzzle end of a late H&R M1, designed wrench to closely fit its high-hump gas block, will also fit the earlier no-hump gas blocks.

Recommend printing ABS with a high density fill. Be sure to allow the bed to pre-heat an extended time to prevent warping and de-lamination. You can check the print to ensure it is scaled correctly by measuring the hole in the handle, which has a diameter of 7.62mm as drawn.

Bore guide designed to limit muzzle damage from cleaning rods, for use with the M1 rifle. This guide is designed for a more secure fit than those that can be purchased from commercial vendors, as it indexes off the gas cylinder lock screw.
I created this muzzle guide from the ground-up by measuring my late H&R M1 rifle. This guide has a 6.8mm hole for use with a Dewey .30 caliber coated rod.

author: rshonk

description.text:
Colors collide in this fabulous device. Was it made by aliens? Is it a mechanism for sending kaleidoscopic messages to motley colored extraterrestrials?

Build one and you'll find out!

Video of thing in action: https://youtu.be/7xYOKNmgrpg

Latest News: This thing has been featured on 3dprint.com:
http://3dprint.com/79623/3d-printed-rainbow-apparatus

This project involves soldering, small-parts, electrical components and an extremely bright LED. You assume all risks and liabilities should you wish to undertake it.

Print it:

The lamp consists of several parts that snap together. You will need one base, three pillars, a top ring, and a cover.

I have also included an EXPERIMENTAL projection disc. The Rainbow Apparatus arose from the idea that you could paint a picture using light rather than pigments. My original concept called for projection discs that could be loaded on the platform of the Rainbow Apparatus. This idea proved far too ambitious for my 3D printer and my attempt at a color logo led to a jumbled mess. I do not recommend you print the projection disc unless you have access to a very high accuracy printer.

Light it up:

I used three 20mm high-power LED stars for my build. I chose red, green and royal blue LEDs because these are primary additive colors. When their lights mix you can get four additional colors (cyan, yellow, magenta and white)

A pack of ten LEDs of each color costs less than $5 on eBay. The LEDs are rated at up to 3W. I strung all LEDs together in series and am driving them at about 9V.

Be careful not to look directly at the LED. It is extremely bright and could damage your eyes.

Power it:

A string of LEDs in series will begin running at about 8V-9V, so you will need a suitable power supply. I used a bench-top adjustable power supply for testing, but in my final build I used a recycled 12V wall wart combined with a adjustable micro DC-DC step-down converter from e-bay. The particular one I used was listed as "10pcs Mini DC-DC Converter Step Down Module Adjustable Output 1-17V for RC PLANE" and sold by axeprice. It was small enough to fit in the base of the lamp, but you could also mount a larger module outside of the lamp. The converter has an adjustable output voltage, so you can tune the brightness of the LEDs and balance it against heat output.

Choosing the correct voltage:

Because in my build I did not use resistors, picking the correct voltage for the LEDs is very critical. The LED string will begin conducting at a certain voltage, but beyond that, the current will increase very sharply. The sweet spot is only a few tenths of a volt beyond the initial conduction point. I recommend using a bench-top power supply with a variable voltage knob and an integrated ammeter to determine the voltage that causes enough current to run through the LED without overheating (about 0.4A for a 3W LED). Once you have determined the correct voltage, re-check it using a multimeter and write it down. You will use this voltage to tune the DC-to-DC converter during assembly.

Assemble it:

Assembly consists of soldering the various parts together. Be very careful about the polarity of the components. The following build sequence worked for me:

  • Cut the plug off your AC wall wart and separate the two wires.
  • Solder the wires to the input pads of your DC-to-DC converter (In+ and In-). Use a multimeter to determine which wire is positive and which is negative if you cannot tell. Polarity is very important.
  • Plug in the AC wall wart and using the multimeter adjust the voltage on your DC-to-DC converter to the value you determined above. If you do not have a multimeter, set it to 7V to start -- this will keep you from blowing out your LED when you first power it up.
  • Position the LEDs on the base and determine the length of wire you will need to wire them up.
  • Solder the three LEDs in series. A set of set of bench top helping hands is very good for this task. Be careful of the polarity, the + of one LED needs to be soldered to the - of the next.
  • At the beginning and end of the LED chain, solder two longer lengths of wire, preferably of two different colors, so you can keep track of which is positive and which is negative.
  • Glue down the LEDs to the wells on the base and feed the terminal wires down one of the vertical shafts.
  • Flip over the base. Solder the other end of the wires to the output terminals of the DC-to-DC converter. Mind the polarity -- if you get it reversed, the LED will not light.
  • Position the DC-to-DC converter to the recess and secure with glue or electrical tape.

Tune it:

Once you first plug it in, run your lamp without the cover and monitor it to make sure the LEDs are not getting too hot. Let it run a couple minutes and checking regularly to make sure that it is not getting too hot to the touch. If it is, dial back the voltage on the DC-to-DC converter.

You want the LEDs to run warm, but not hot enough to melt the plastic or cause a fire hazard. Do not run the lamp unattended until you have monitored it for several hours to make sure heat is not a problem.

Customize it:

This design is fully customizable. Be sure to check it out in the Makerbot customizer!

title: Handelbar mount for Samsung S5 with wireless Qi charging - weather proof

description.text:
2016-03-28: Update
Version 16 is now ready and tested! Better! Stronger! Smoother!

This is a handlebar mount for Samsung Galaxy S5. It will not only allow you to safely place the phone at a good position for you to see your GPS app, speedometer, music app or whatever, but it will actually allow you to charge the phone at the same time - wirelessly!
Put the phone in the mount, flip the self-locking top and start driving.

Made for a 1" handlebar, but can easily be used on smaller diameter handlebar by just placing a thin rubber sheet or a few layers of electrical tape between the handlebar and the mount.

I've done a LOT of revisions during the last year but were never quite happy with them until now. This is version 16, so a lot of tweaks and practical solutions has been added over time. The size may seem a bit large at first, but it has its reasons;

  1. Stability. You don't want it breaking apart and dropping your precious phone when going 140km/h.
  2. Safety; to add a safe distance for the wireless charger not to be affected by other metal objects, like handlebars.
  3. Clearance. To get clear of any handlebar clamps that fixes the handlebar to the bike. Tested and verified on a Suzuki VL800 Volusia with risers.

Small tweaks:

  • Self-locking visor/lid. While the visor is closed, it is impossible to move the phone up more than a tiny bit, which in itself locks the visor using the sidebars inside of the visor. Additionally, the air pushes the lid down while riding.
  • Visor come in three different sizes, print the one you want.
  • Access to all buttons, including Volume up/down, Home and Power
    (     Power button requires you to first flip the lid open).
  • Access to headset jack.
  • Lower side walls, making it more easy to lift the phone from the mount.
  • Recess for the camera. Minimizes the risk of scratching the lens.
  • Immersed holes for nuts and bolts for a clean look and better stability.
  • Drain holes for rain water.

There are a bunch of Wireless Qi pucks on eBay for about 3€. I bought mine there and it has been working great mounted on my motorcycle since about 10'000 kilometers back (note: this was on an earlier version of the mount - new version is even stronger). Alternatively, disassemble any cheap Qi charger or get a DIY kit and hot glue it to the inside of the center cover - this allows you to line up the charger perfectly with your receiver pad in the phone.

Shopping list:

  • If your phone don't already have it, you need a Qi receiver for your phone. Search eBay or your favorite electronic store for "S5 Qi receiver".
  • 1 x Qi charger, 69x9mm or DYI kit. Search eBay or your favorite electronic store for "Qi charger". This is often bundled with the S5 Qi receiver, so you can save a buck by buying them together.
  • 5 x M6 bolts, stainless steel with round Allen head. Should be 40mm long (not including the head).
  • 5 x M6 locking nuts, stainless steel.
    Total price: less than 7€.

You also need to provide power to the charger. You can either use:

  • A battery pack with a USB outlet
  • A standard 12V jack with a cigarette plug to USB.
    (these two can be found everywhere)
  • A 12V to MicroUSB adapter. This is what I use, through a relay to make sure that it's only charging when the bike is running.

For more information see http://www.frankjohansson.com/3d-printed-handlebar-phone-mount-with-wireless-charging-for-galaxy-s5/, where I describe in detail how to assemble it, including the electronics. Lots of photos!

Note: Photos are from version 15, but instructions are identical.

I printed with PLA at 0.1 height, 75% infill to be on the safe side.

I've been using an earlier version in unpainted PLA for a couple of months and it's held up fine, riding about 50 km/day, but ABS, Nylon or PETG might be better.

USE SUPPORT.
If needed, slowly(!) drill out holes with a 6mm bit to make sure the bolts goes through smoothly.

Place the Qi charger in the main slot of the mount. You may have to remove the top and bottom rubber rings on the charger (they are just glued in place). The MicroUSB port on the charger should be facing down the bottom hole. Then place the the Qi cover over it. If it's not tight enough to stay there, use some silicon, hot glue or sugru on the edges of the cover to keep in place. (make sure the charger is actually working before that), this will keep rain out of your changer. The phone itself is already waterproof.
If the phone is not connecting with the charger, or keeps loosing connection, the charger and receiver are not lined up. Check exactly in what position the receiver is located in your phone, open up the charger case and place the charger coil so that it lines up with the receiver. Use hot glue or Sugru to fasten the charger guts inside the Qi cover.

Attach the whole mount with M6 bolts (from the clamp) to the body (M6 locking nuts). Once they are in position and the mount is at a good angle, tighten the bolts.

Next, place the Lock at the top, lining it up with the to hole in the body. Use an stainless or plastic M6 bolt as hinge center, make sure it's not magnetic (see if a magnet will stick to it). Otherwise, just use a zip tie and you're good to go.

Drive safely.

comments.text: Frank, thanks for putting this together.  I printed it and it looks great.  I had a few issues with installing the visor.  I printed at 50% infill and .2mm layer height and the hinge seems prone to breaking when I tighten the nut.  Also, do you use M6 washers with the visor as well?  The visor mount seems to fit a bit loose, can you provide a visor version that's a little tighter?  Thanks!
comments.author: aznoohwee

comments.text:
Hi aznoohwee, glad you like it!
I have no issues with the visor (Medium). I don't use washers and have tightened mine hard enough so that it can stay in the upright position on it's own, yet can be closed without effort. If the hinge fit seems too lose for you and you are afraid you might break it when tightening, your washer suggestion seems right. You can print your own from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647 > Open in Customizer > Type: Washer > Washer-options, then set the values that matches the gap in your print exactly.
comments.author: aznoohwee

comments.text: My charger didn't line up perfectly with my phone's Qi receiver pad, which made it lose and regain contact a bit too often. I ended up gutting the charger puck and hot-gluing the charger spool and circuit board to the inside of the printed Qi cover in a position that lined up better with the receiver. Now it connects fine and seems to stay that way.

remixed_from.author: autom8it
remixed_from.title: Cooling Fan Bracket and Shroud for Ecksbot 3D Printer

description.text: This is a print cooler I designed for my Ecksbot. I had been using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58306 for quite some time which actually worked well. My biggest problem with the front-mounted print cooler is that it was constantly in my way when trying to clean the nozzle, or just when observing my printer in action. I wrote this part using OpenSCAD and I've included the .scad file as well in case you find that your particular application needs adjustments. This cooler is designed to simply clip onto the extruder cooling shroud on the Ecksbot, however I found that it can shift and rattle during really fast/aggressive infils, so I added a loop for a cable tie to keep it secured. The same 40mm fan used on the extruder cooler is also used for this as well. Eckertech sells them for $5 apiece (I'm in their area often for local pickup), or you might find one elsewhere if you're lucky (I wasn't). This print cooler will allow you to decrease your minimum layer time to at least 10 seconds per layer if not less than that. I included a picture of a red tree frog (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18479) I printed it at 0.05mm layer height, 500 layers, in about 2 hours (Skeinforge default would take over 8 hours at minimum 60 seconds per layer).

Hopefully you will only need to print the .stl I uploaded, but if you need/want to tweak the design a little, feel free to play with the .scad.  Nothing special to print this, I used 0.3mm layer height at 30% infill.  The print will likely NOT want to come off your bed and it is quite fragile/thin, so you'll need to be careful.  I've printed at least a dozen trials of these during development and I've found that the best method for removal is to use a clean, flexible paint scraper and to work it off gently starting at the fan clip.  Install the 40mm fan using a pair of M4 x 40mm bolts and nuts.  Wire your existing extruder cooler to be fed from constant 12V power and then wire the print cooler to the D09 output instead to allow PWM control.  
In general, I print most objects with the print cooler off for the first 3 layers to ensure good adhesion, then I turn it on 50% or so for the remaining.  If the layer time is fast (<15 seconds) I might go higher to 70-80%.  Skeinforge doesn't seem to have support to do this automatically, but I believe Slic3r does have something for this.

title: Enclosure for miniSpartan6+ FPGA Dev Board

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the Scarab Hardware miniSpartan6+ FPGA dev board ( http://www.scarabhardware.com/minispartan6/ ). The miniSpartan6+ is a nice low-cost Xilinx Spartan 6 FPGA board with 2x HDMI ports, USB, uSD, audio, etc.

The enclosure can be used simply as a base for the board to snap into, leaving the top open... or you can print the top, which snaps onto the base, enclosing the board. There are two tops - one with the Scarab Hardware logo, the other with no logo. There are screw holes in the bottom, in case you want to attach the board to the base.

There are openings for both HDMI ports, the headphone port, the Mini USB port, and the uSD slot... as well as holes to access the DIP switches, reset switch, and windows for the LEDs.

The I/O expansion connectors are unobstructed inside the case, though I don't personally use them for anything right now, so I didn't create any openings for them. Openings for the I/O connectors can easily be added to the lid and/or the base.

I printed this in black ABS using standard settings at 0.3mm layer height. While there are a few small overhangs, I used no support (the angles aren't too steep).

Once both pieces are printed, snap the miniSpartan6+ into the base and snap the top onto the base. If you're using just the base, you can use #2 (or metric equivalent) screws to attach the miniSpartan6+ to the base.

description.text: 6" across. Printed in 3 hours, PLA.

Update:

Fixed a couple errors in the scad that I introduced while modifying it for the customizer. Also cleaned up the outer ring so that it will be more reliably smooth. Not sure if the customizer will bring in the changes, so I may end up re-uploading to a different thing file.

This is designed for use when doing acetone treatment of ABS objects, but you could use it for a variety of other purposes. I use a paint can lined with paper towels soaked in acetone (see http://airwolf3d.com/2013/11/26/7-steps-shiny-finish-on-abs-parts-acetone/). I printed the racks in PLA, so they would not dissolve in the acetone vapor bath.

I designed this for use in acetone vapor treatment of ABS. The racks shown in the photos were printed in PLA, which is not soluble in acetone. However, after a couple treatments I found that exposure to acetone vapor does weaken the PLA so it sagged quite a bit.

I increased the thickness of all the rack dimensions, and my new rack seems to hold up better.

Kinda new here, this may be useful to some people who would like to measure and re-measure your Prusa Mendel build. I've designed it so that you could use a printer or laser cutter, cnc etc. So its easy to make:)
Print, cut or paste... Have fun:)

title: Apple Key Fob... The must have 'Apple Logo' shaped Key Fob for Apple / iPhone / iPad Fans

description.text:
Apple / iPhone / iPad owners will appreciate this little 'accessory'...

This Apple logo shaped key fob is best printed in two colours. Just pause your machine as per the instructions provided and change your filament colour to suit.

At standard size it measure approx. 32mm (W) x 40mm (H) x 6mm thick so is quick and easy to print. There is a small amount of designed in support that should come away easily along with the Raft.

Note: If you like this check out all my other designs!

On a Replicator 2 this prints well at Standard 0.20mm Resolution / 3 Shells / 65% infill (so it is strong and will last well on your key ring).

With MakerBot Desktop if you use Raft change colours at 2mm (35% complete) and 6mm (85% complete. The mm change points can be set to automatically pause the machine on 4th Generation MakerBot's but on 5th Generation models and other machines you will need to manually pause it around the percentages given.

If you aren't using Raft change at 1mm and 5mm (I.e. Raft is approx. 1.0mm to 1.2mm thick).

Refer to the images provided for more information.

Fishing action video! https://vid.me/JGd6

If the clam won't fit, you must eat it. Or something like that. Set the large hole to the minimum clam size according to your local regs, and then you can test the clams you dig to make sure they are legal. In my area, the clam is legal if there is at least one orientation that won't fit through the hole.

To make one, just click on the "Open in Customizer" button to the right, choose metric or imperial, enter the minimum clam size you are targeting in mm or inches (fyi, 1.5" is 38.1 mm), and enter your printer nozzle size. After you print it, make sure the clam hole measures correctly so you don't end up keeping too small clams -- you can make fine adjustments by tweaking the nozzle size variable.

Note: If you download as opposed to using customizer, and want the text to print, you will need to use the "write" project and modify the "use <Write/write.scad>" line in clamGauge.scad to indicate where the files are: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193

title: Tripod Mount for iPhone 6 Plus with Thule Atmos X3

description.text:
It allows you to keep your case on the camera and utilizes the rubber-ness of the case for a snug and secure fit, without undue clamping stress being placed on the iPhone itself.

For mounting iPhone 6 Plus with the Thule Atmos X3 case. Snugly wraps around the case and provides 3 x 1/4-20 mounting options.

The part is a bit bulkier than it needs to be, but it was designed to print well, it's solid and will hold your iPhone securely.

If you don't have this Thule case, this will not work for you. But this case is highly recommended, well worth owning if you need a case anyway.

It is most secure when mounted on the center of the camera as it is widest at the center, but will be still usable if you only push the mount about 20mm up from the bottom.

Printed 0.2mm layer height, 33% infill, 2 shells, 1mm floor & roof, support for the holes, printed using Prototype Supply PLA (from Toy Builder Labs).

Insert 3 x TriStar Inserts (H2520 x 364P), little bit of soldering iron, little bit of push. (May be hard to find these inserts, sorry).

Slides snugly onto iPhone Six with the Atmos X3 case. Best to slide from bottom up to avoid buttons.

description.text:
This is a remix of the light theme from Foxy. Which is itself a remix of the orginal Notepad++ language support from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167899

It has an updated set of keyword for current OpenSCAD.
It is a replacement for the OpenSCAD_lang.xml file in the original post.

To replace the language file in the original - you must remember to "remove" the existing OpenSCAD entry when you open "Language" / "Define your language".

I love the new Scintilla in OpenSCAD but Notepad++ gives me auto highlighting when I select, which is super useful for finding where I used a variable, etc.
Hopefully I won't need it much longer. Integration is very good though. Autocompletion etc.. wondeful job.
Then import this new one. (see original docs). Only this step needs to be repeated if you installed the original first.

Remix inspired by multiple sources.

Since I am using magnets on the rail support, either clip works fine.

There is a raised notch on the rail support to help you align the 2 pieces.

When using the larger clip with the rail support, the fit is very tight and magnets are not really needed.

When using the smaller clip with the rail support, magnets are highly recommended.

The 2 magnets I use are Neodymium Magnets 8mm round x 3mm thick.

You might want to glue them on if they are too loose, but they seem to work fine with the current slots under the rail support.

title: Prusa i3 foot with screw mounts

description.text:
Prusa i3 foot with wide base plate and screw holes

  • modeled after another item found on this site

Note: I did not use any of the existing scad file from reference model, I made this from scratch (more as a challenge than anything else).

Openscad source included.

Enjoy.
Gazzew

This was modeled after an existing "thing" here on this site.
Included is the Open-SCAD source I created.

  • fully modularized with variables at top for easy edits/mods.

I did not include zip tie cutouts by choice - feel free to add them if you prefer to use them.

Slice at .20mm height - I printed in ABS on heated bed (auto bed leveling) and didn't have any lift at the corners. YMMV.

When Slicing, mirror the Y-axis to get the other corresponding foot.
I'm not sure how to do in Slic3r, or Cura, but easy to do in KISSlicer.

title: Modular Sand Castle (Work In Progress: More parts to come)

description.text: This is a collection of molds that interlock together, enabling the creation of larger sand castles. As to be expected, the function of these toys is to be filled with wet sand and turned over to create sand castles with ease. The pieces interlock with a simple peg and hole mechanism. The parts are made of a cheap and strong ABS plastic, finished with a dark green paint, so they are lightweight, cheap, last long, and can be 3D printed. These parts were created in Autodesk Inventor 2016 Professional. Feel free to download these files so you can edit them or 3D print them.

CookieCaster cookie cutters are easily printed on your MakerBot using the standard settings - we recommend using PLA to print and then saran wrap for cutting to make cleanup easy and to prevent any loose plastic from getting in your cookies

I have been looking at the X Axis mods on Thingiverse using the roller bearings and decided to take a different slant on the subject.
I decided to try some linear ball race bushes as used on CNC engravers and routers.
I managed to track down some 3/8 inch id bushes with an od of the exact size that fits the existing holes which are holding the plain bushes.
The X table now moves as if it is floating on air.
After seeing this result I intend getting another two to put on my Y axis.

The bushes are such a snug fit that after a one and a half hour print there was no movement in them.
If there is any movement of them in the future it will be quite easy to put a little touch of adhesive on them.

description.text:
Mostly printed CNC custom Spindle mount and bearing-motor holder for International version (25mm pipe diameter).
Work still in progress...

You need:

3 ball bearings: 608-2S

ER11 shaft like this one:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/C10-ER11A-100L-Collet-Chuck-Holder-CNC-Milling-Extension-Rod-Straight-Shank-/151314160125?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item233b06d9fd

some outrunner motor + ESC:
2212 A2212 980KV Brushless Motor + 30A Simonk ESC 3A BEC

1 Arduino to generate PWM signal and startup sequence for the ESC (UNO,Nano, mini, ect).

some washer for spacing.

GT2 belt and pulleys:
belt: 150-2GT
1x 16T with 5mm bore
1x 36T with 8mm bore

comments.author: antonios3d

comments.text: With 12V PSU, it has about 5100RPM...if i'm right. What about a power ? Can it mill aluminium ? I mean like 0.05mm per pass. Is the printed part durable enough for it ?
comments.author: Seeder98

comments.text:
I'm not sure. maybe this will able to mill aluminium or i think this capability depend much more on the machine rigidity than the spindle power itself.
Deffenetly can work with very light materials, if you need to mill hard wood or maybe aluminium try to use the evolved version of this spindle.
Regarding the PSU: I'm using DPS-600PB PSU to power the MPCNC and the Brushless motor.
comments.author: Seeder98

comments.text:
I'm actually going to combine upgraded version (spindle and Y axis, probably aluminium plate) of this http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-printed-CNC-mill/
and your spindle design.
comments.author: gyebi

comments.text:

check the other versions too:
comments.author: Seeder98

comments.text: hi,
comments.author: Seeder98

comments.text:
Hi Alted,
Yes, this is for your AWESOME CNC :-) actually this is for the INTERNATIONAL version because i'm living in EU.
I found this review for the Cheap Chinese spindle: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7P5THNNjafU
After that i decided to go another way to build a spindle.
Actually i just powered up couple times so this is really a proof of concept now. This design seems very stable but it can generate moderate amount of heat so maybe i need to print ABS instead of PLA, maybe i need to put a cooling fan on top of the shaft.
I will test is soon... in case if it is melting because of the generated heat i will print another one (ABS), or maybe we can mill a new one from tougher plastic :-)

Wide wheel option for the Econo1Bots. I used the rubber bands from around produce as well as cut bicycle inner tubes for traction.  I'm not sure if updates get notified so....I have also updated the Econo1_1Bot.
Stops your RepRap I2 slowly taking a walk across your desk. Simple as that.

Print in TPU or your favorite flexible filament.

Remember the rules of flexible filament:-

Print slowly and at a constant rate so as not to vary the pressure in the hot-end or cause a ruckus. Typical flexible filament speeds I've been achieving are 19mm/s, much more and I end up untangling my extruder.

Print with the fan OFF.

Too much heat and you're print will curl, too little and your extruder will tangle in filament.

Don't be shy, use a large layer height and extrude on the thick side.

Print 4 of them.

Some of you might need to print this part with a brim or whatnot otherwise it may curl at the edges.

I included the FreeCAD file so you can change it anyway.

author: MagicMuh

title: Goal Post joints for 600 x 350mm goal

description.text:
I was asked to attend the Royl Cornwall Show in the UK with my work this week, and I am going to be demonstrating Robotic Football using our teaching robots.
Thing is, all the goals were being used, so I wanted something visually good looking to represent the goal.
What better way to do this than to make a set of goals!

Print 2 of each part.
Using overflow pipe (OD 22mm ID about 19.8mm) cut to the required lengths to make your goal. This can be made using a standard 3 meter length of pipe. Mine is designed to accommodate robots standing 35cm tall. The lengths i cut were:
1 x 600mm cross bar
2 x 90mm top corner
2 x 330mm front bars
2 x 350mm side base
2 x 415mm hypotenuse bars. push the 3 corner piece into the 90mm, 330mm and 600mm piece.
Push the 2 corner piece into the 330mm and 350mm piece.
Push the 2 rear bent piece into the 415mm piece.
push the 2 bent corner piece into the other end of the 415mm piece and into the 90mm piece. Create the other side in the same fashion to create a goal post! Set your robots off on their quest to reign supreme in the 2050 world cup! I have attached the original sketchup files, as only 1 part has rounded edges. I run out of time to make them all rounded.

title: Dolly for GoPro and Mobius action cam

description.text:
English.

You also have another version available in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1598707

Go for a walk with your camera and make videos action from a different point of view. With this simple dolly can be done very simply with funny videos and if you push it links the selfie your stick, you will not have to crouch.

The wheels are attached with screws 6 mm.
The shafts are attached to the platform with screws of 5 mm.
Sefie stick is attached to the platform with a nut 1/4 "
The patella is taken from a cheap desktop tripod and attached to the platform with a screw 4 mm.

If you make one dolly, put a link to the video in the comments. It will be fun!

Español.

Tienes además otra versión disponible en http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1598707

Sal a pasear con tu cámara de acción y haz vídeos desde un punto de vista diferente. Con esta sencilla dolly se pueden hacer vídeos muy divertidos simplemente con empujar y si le acoplas tu palo de selfie, no tendrás que agacharte.

Las ruedas se sujetan con tornillos de 6 mm (las ruedas las he comprado en Decathlon por 11 euros y venían 8).
Los ejes se sujetan a la plataforma con tornillos de 5 mm.
El palo de sefie se sujeta a la plataforma con una tuerca de 1/4"
La rótula está sacada de un trípode barato de sobremesa y se sujeta a la plataforma con un tornillo de 4 mm.

Si te fabricas una dolly, pon un enlace al vídeo en los comentarios. ¡Será divertido!

comments.text: Do you have some actual footage of this Dolly? I'd like to see that before i start printing.
comments.author: imarkee

author: fbuenonet

title: Go Pro/Xiaomi Yi Ball & Socket Mount for Da Vinci

description.text: This is a simple ball & socket mount for action cams to record/monitor prints. Clips onto the inside of the printer frame and uses a standard 1/4" x 10-20mm bolt to attach the cam.

1. Print parts
  2. Attach the socket to the end of the bracket using the adhesive of your choice
  3. Screw 1/4" x 10-20mm bolt into ball and screw onto action cam
  4. Clip the bracket/socket assembly to the upper left hole in the Da Vinci frame
  5. Push the ball into the socket
  6. Adjust as needed
  7. Happy Printing

description.text:
ZERO ENERGY WRITING POCKET RATTLE
No batteries, no solar cells, just manpower!

An electronics project for printing people, should be without the necessity to make a printed circuit board (not everybody has that capability). Only very simple and basic soldering is required. In spite of that, the project has a certain level of complexity. That’s why Arduino comes in. The Nano3V has a small footprint and is very low cost. A simple monochrome 10 led air writer, based on persistence of vision (POV) , is presented here. Easy to make, without skills in electronics

We probably all played with a rattle as a child. Turning it around, making lots of noise. So we will make a rattle! Since a green project gives a better chance to win the Makerbot, we add a small geared DC motor to the rattle to generate the electricity for the Arduino . The energy is supplied by the user of this gadget himself .

When blinking leds are moved through the air, we see dotted lines. With ten leds in a row, blinking in a synchronized way, we can write characters in the air. A small geared dc motor has to supply about 12 volts. The geared motor shown, or something similar, is exactly what we need. Buy it here
http://www.aliexpress.com/snapshot/6604610388.html?orderId=66765675522572
or use the specification to select one yourself.
The SCAD file is included for eventual adaptions to the motor size.
By rotating the 3D printed mid air led printer, the leds move in a circle, writing lines in the air.
Arduino synchronizes the blinking of the individual leds. The color of the leds can be chosen as long as the right series resistor is used. For 20 mA green and blue leds, a resistor of 82 (or 100) Ohms is used. For red leds we need 150 Ohms. Make sure the leds are diffuse. A clear led throws the light in a bundle and is not visible outside the angle of the beam. A diffuse led is visible from all angles.

The NanoV3 is plugged into a mini breadboard, widely available in electronic shops.
Ten leds are mounted into the housing and the series resistors are soldered to the longer led wire. The resistor wires are connected to the breadboard in such a way that they correspond with Arduino port numbers D3-D12. The short led wires are all connected to Gnd. To make soldering a bit easier for beginners, the box has plenty of room. The dynamo wires got to V-in and Gnd. Check which one is positive (with a voltmeter or a led) when you rotate the handle, before actually connecting them. You will notice that the rattle prevents you from rotating in the wrong direction.
Shrink tube is perfect to fix the motor wire to the extensions.
The case is not only a housing, when rotated it takes care of the necessary centrifugal forces as well. The distance between dynamo and leds is about 30 cm. However, the entire thing can be folded to pocket size.
When you take it out of your pocket and unfold it in one move, it works immediately. Your audience will be surprised. This gadget can be used in many places. It can show the name of your favorite sports club, or your loved one when you bring a serenade or WELCOME when you pick up someone at the airport. Or it shows HAPPY BIRTHDAY when you visit a friend or GOOD MORNING entering the office.

An example program for Arduino is included. It clearly shows how characters are build up row after row. Play with the timing to influence dot width and character spacing.

The text moves around in mid air, the position changes and depends on delay times in the program, the speed of rotation and the length of the text. To stabilize the text, a reed switch is activated by a neodymium magnet in the grip. A 10K resistor keeps A5 to 5Volt until the reed switch closes. The wires run through channels to the other side of the housing. Take care of proper insulation with a piece of tape. Adjust the position of the magnet in such a way that the reed switch closes and opens during a rotation and fix it with some tape or shrink tube. At the point it closes, the text will start, always at the same position.
To optimize exposure, the (modest) rattling will draw attention. If the text is upside down, reverse the following order of the port numbers 3-12 in the Arduino sketch.
https://youtu.be/rEn0A5Q5Hw8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9UMbsx2-I3E

title: PebbleTime Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Not happy with the short design, I decided to make this dock that is taller and displays the Pebble time nicely.
The dock is simple yet functional, the USB cable fits perfectly in the dock, the cable is incorporated in the design and comes out the back nicely.

The PebbleTime can sit securely on the dock even without the charging cable in case you just use it as a display dock.

Hope you like it.

**If you don't have a 3D printer look this dock up in Etsy.

Just print with supports, they are minimal so there will not be much wasted material.

PLA is fine with 2 shells and 10% infil, its pretty sturdy and prints in around 2 1/2 hours. (Replicator2)

I tried printing with Laywood but the material was too soft even at 50% infill, I had to add a bent metal wire to help support (guess my Laywood was more flexible than I thought)

Hope you like it and let me know if it works out for you.

Cheers

comments.text: The supports on the purple one looks superb. Any chance for a STL or GCode with these sweet supports?
comments.author: bhorn

comments.text: I use the standard rafting from Makerware with 2 wall layers and 10% infill. I Use PLA and the sizing is perfect to keep the cable snug. I can add the .x3g file if you guys need, it would be the same file I use.
comments.author: otaku

comments.text: Is there any possibility of posting the print ready files.  It would be nice to have prints that need support included with supports in the stl file that work for sure.  I get mixed results adding supports with the software that came with my printer, would be nice see those supported versions just to learn how everyone else's supports look to learn from for us newer into 3d printing.  Any chance you can post a supported version?
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: So, I printed one out, using Meshmixer to generate supports, which worked out ok.  It simply wouldn't let me manually place them where I wanted, so I just let it do it's thing.  A couple of recommendations to anyone about to print, I would change the way the cord exits the stand first. It really gives it a kink and I just dremeled it out to avoid kinking the cord. If you want a good fit, try 98% scale or something, because cord end dropped right in and comes out when you pull the watch off the stand. I think 98% scale would give it a nice snug fit.  Other than those two things I recommend modifying, its working great!
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: Hi, I used the standard supports from Makerware, its a free software. Maybe give it a try, it willmake a Gcode file for i guess any printer. Maybe have a look, if that doesnt work I can upload the one I used. but that way you can control how much support and infill you need.

description.text: This dust shoe should allow for simultaneous minimalspray- or air- cooling while keeping the workplace clean.

Print or CNC the parts.
Superglue neodymium magnets 10mm x 1mm (Wait till dry, then repeat gluing the edges several times for a secure fit)
Tap the base unit (M3)
Secure the vacuum tube mount using M3 screws (3x)
Hammer in the brush strip (mine had an 8 X 8 mm rubber strip)
Attach using M5 screws (3x)

DXF and Openscad here for modification. CNC the parts or render in openscad and export .stl files for printing.

description.text:
This is a coin holder designed to fit any cup holder that can hold a pop can.
Coin holder 1 is 1.1 inches tall and holds 1 inch of coins,
Coin holder 2 is 2.1 inches tall and holds 2 inch of coins,
Coin holder 3 is 3.1 inches tall and holds 3 inch of coins,
Coin holder v2 is 3 inches tall and holds 1.5 inch of coin.
The Version 1 of this is for shallow cup holders.
Coin Holder V3 is 2.1 inches tall and holds 2 inch of coin and has a hole all the way threw to allow a base to snap on to it. I have upload 5 different base sizes from 1 inch to 2.5 inch so you can print the top section that holds the coins and pick witch base that will give you the right height for you cup holder. Also this will make it handing if you decide to move it to a different cup holder that all you have to do is print a new base and not the hole thing. another plus is now you can rotate the coin holder.
I have all so upload a coin holder lid that will snap on the top so when you move your coin holder you won't lose any of you coins.
The base and lid will be snug so you make need to do a little clean up to make them if as easy as you want.

title: The Adafruit RFID Breakout Board Wand for MakerBot

description.text: UPDATE! I apologize! I uploaded the wrong back-end model yesterday, and just realized it last night when I tried to print it! :o I've uploaded the right models now, tested and working as of Tues 5/21/13. :) This is a wand/protector for the Adafruit RFID Breakout Board that I'm using in my RiderScan project: http://www.adafruit.com/products/364 It's one of the best RFID/NFC breakout boards around, and since I'll be using mine in a Horse Barn environment, I needed an enclosure that could stand up to wear and tear, as well as be functional and easy to use. This is my 2nd attempt to make such an enclosure using Blender and my trust MakerBot Replicator - I have ideas for a 3rd design in the works now. The board is made by Kevin Townsand of Adafruit, and is a particularly well-made product - really ahead of it's time. Branded with both the Adafruit and MakerBot logo's, this is my Nod to both of these fabulous companies - some of the best modelling I think I've done to date, and I hope the community finds it useful for your projects as well :) And of course, you know where to find the MakerBot Replicator!! http://www.makerbot.com I'm making updates to the handle today, and will post a new version soon! Kris

I created the models such that they will firmly connect together, and yet pull-apart again when you need to access the internals. You may want to add one or more rubber o-rings around the outside to make it waterproof.
  • The models can be printed in any type of plastic, ABS or PLA works great. It's designed for single extrusion. The two .STL models are saved in the exact position that you need to print it as, but just in case:
    • 1a. The front model (with the Adafruit logo) is printed on it's Side (either side will do). You'll notice the sides are smooth, just put that on the platform and it will print. 1b. The back/handle model is printed on it's end, with the base or hilt of the handle sitting on the platform so that it's standing upright.

  • Solder a set of 90 degree bend header to the breakout board (like these: http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/M20-9960645/952-2247-ND/3728211)

  • Make sure to solder the SEL0 and SEL1 pins on the breakout board (don't use header here, you need the board to remain as flat as possible to fit into the front-end. For default/SPI use, solder the two OFF pins for SEL0, and the two ON pins for SEL1.

  • Once printed, simply insert the Adafruit RFID breakout board into the slot designed for it on the Front-End of the model and push it all the way in. It's a snug fit, and that's intentional.

  • If you want to add the optional LEDs, push them through the openings on both sides and run the wires through the center of the handle. As in the pictures, I found it useful to solder male header onto the ends so that I can adjust which pin plugs into where on the Arduino end at the controller more easil.

  • Connect the wires onto the header on the RFID board and LEDs, and run the wires through the handle. Use waterproof wire connectors if you plan to use this outdoors (like: http://www.adafruit.com/products/744)
    • Your good to go! I will update these instructions with the Adafruit forum post that shows how to wire it all together, but for now you can look at the RiderScan prototype post for details on how I plan to use it. http://forums.adafruit.com/viewtopic.php?f=25&t=22139 Thanks and let me know if you have any feedback!! :) Good luck! Kris

title: Build plate using 8" x 10" glass pane with adapter brackets

description.text:
A redesign of my original brackets to accommodate a digital bed leveler dial remix I was working on. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911364

!!! IMPORTANT: Should be used in conjunction with a print bed height adapter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911247 to manually set at a safe distance between the bed and nozzle to avoid damage during leveling. !!!

Recommend adjusting the nozzle levels if needed using: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911406

Implemented various recommendations. The files have been repaired through Netfabb.

I created these sturdier brackets to support standard 8 x 10 picture frame glass panes, but also to accommodate smaller metal clips.

The tip of the digital dial no longer strikes the side of the rear right bracket while leveling the raised glass plate.

I can swap out the glass and continue to print without waiting for the cool down period. Placing blue tape on one side is also a time saver.

Print each bracket twice.

Raft and Supports are recommended.

Should fit CTC style 3D printer with 6" x 9" build plates that have hardware at corners of plate to hold the support brackets.

title: Vertex 3D Printer K8400 Glass plate holder

description.text:
I have been struggling to keep the glass plate level on my K8400, the aluminum holder is curved in the middle, thus hitting the printed objects and ruining the print. This is a mod using the plate clip and putting it a little bit on the center of the back panel. For the front I use ordinary clip.

Forcefully bending the alu plate did not work for me.

Printed with PLA 30% infill - .2mm layer height

Super glued the 2 original clips to the printed object and now bed is level on all sides and in the middle.

If ever you change your mind you can always remove it and put all the original pieces back to their respective place. Superglue dissolves in acetone.

comments.text: Been there, did not do that. Try to bend it that is. The aluminum plate has a slight dome shape from the manufacturing and can not be bended right. You should send a ticket to Velleman support. I did and got a new plate, just as crocked as the first. I have put shims in the corners so the glass don't touch the aluminum plate anywhere.

description.text: When my students work with the Hummingbird Kit, there are always too few wheels that fit the Hummingbird Kit motors. So I made these Ø60mm wheels that fit.

There are a few NES-alike Raspberry PI Cases out there. With this I wanted to create a more advanced version which looks and feels much more like the original NES.

Here it is...my Pitendo Ultimate!

Features:

  • "original" start button
  • "original" reset button
  • Indicator LED
  • built in Wifi
  • built in USB Hub
  • temperature regulated mini fan

Needs a lot of soldering work!
For the Raspberry Pi Model B+ only!!

Improved version for Raspberry Pi B 2 will follow!!

Parts with the number 2 are for those of you, who don't have warping problems

Printed with supports...

There can be found different tutorials how to control LEDs or make buttons to shutdown the PI...
The reset button is connected directly to the hard reset of the PI.
The fan is controlled by a python file which searches for high temperature in the PI CPU

author: danjard_MATHIEU

description.text:
A bare bones mendel using the vinyl tubing vertex as described by mrkim http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8313. So far I have the frame and a Z motor mount. I'm thinking the X motor mount and idler will be similar to Prusa's but backwards and possibly upside down since my smooth rod is inside of my threaded rod rather than vice versa as in the Prusa Mendel. I'll try to keep this page and the reprap wiki page http://reprap.org/wiki/Test_Tube_Mendel as up to date as possible as I make progress. update: 6-20-2011 got the X end idler done. Files are posted. So far the print time savings is as follows (I'll skein these all with same settings soon for apples to apples comparison.) Vertices:
Prusa -> 2x top + 4x footed = about 6.5h printing
Test Tube -> 0h printing Z motor mounts:
Prusa -> 2x motor mount = about 2h printing
Test Tube -> 2x motor clamp, 4x angle rod clamp 2left,2right = about 1h printing (or 0 hours if you use Mrkims idea here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9180 ) Y motor mount:
Prusa -> about 1/2 hour printing
Test Tube -> 0h printing X end Idler:
Prusa -> about 1.5 hour printing
Test Tube -> 1 Idler + 2 idler clamp -> about 1 hour printing

I'm using 5/16 inch threaded rod, but the design is currently (mostly) agnostic about the choice of rod size. I did the entire frame in 15 inch lengths to make scaling easy. I did 15 inch lengths to mimic the Mendel build area, but 12 or 18 inch lengths would be more efficient from a materials standpoint (waste less rod) and might make for some interesting mini and mega versions.
Z motor mount uses 1/4 inch cross bar and a couple printed parts. The cross bar reduces print time for Z motor mount. (about 30 min each set)
The bar clamps are from the Prusa mendel files http://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel.

comments.text: Well, I think this is a very good thing.  If it turns out to be as stable as the current Mendels, then that will reduce the production cost of these things.  At the same time, it also opens up the possibility of using materials other than just threaded steel rods.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: The bare frame seems a little more flexy than the prusa I have, but that should go away once you attach an electronics mounting board. As for other materials, I think anything that doesn't crush could be used for the triangles. The cross bars still have to be threaded though.

This principle can be adapted to other printers . . .

title: Wind Turbine  #CatchTheWind.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My entry for the Thingiverse #CatchTheWind.

I'v been always fascinated about green energy, for the sole reason that is free. After I bought my 3D printer a Vertex Velleman K8400 kit assembled in a 2 days (a good challenge) without any engineering background. I was playing around whit the idea and downloaded a few wind mill designs and printed them. Found a couple nice ones, but I wasn't entirely happy whit them, so I started learning AutoCad (trial) to design my own, started whit the blades.... after a lot of research and beginner tutorials came out whit a relay satisfying blade design, that runs on the smallest breeze, and went from there on to create a body that can contain a dc motor for generating electricity, made it big enough to fit a couple of gears and a solar collector on top for ambient lighting(bought a cheap solar garden light and incorporated the parts) . The "shark fin" tail gives extra sensibility to wind direction also counters the the front weight whit pushing the tail down.
For the generator I took apart a small aquarium pump it has a permanent magnet and low turning resistance, ideal but not the best.
While browsing on the site I found this challenge #CatchTheWind. there are some really good designs, entered and hope for the best. That printer looks amazing

You need:
->4 x bearings inside diameter 10 mm/26 mm outer (just bought some cheap ones)
->3x 5x60 Machine screw and M5 nuts
->13x 5x25 Machine screw and M5 nuts
->M10 filleted rod like 50cm
->8x M10 nuts
->2x M10 washer (bigger than the bearing outer diameter use this and the rod to press the bearings into place it is quite a snug fit )
->Loctite super glue for the blades

The upgrade V4

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:938257 the big one V4

The bike dynamo Wind Turbine (Shimano Capreo DH-F703 6v 3.0w Dynamo QR Front Hub)

So I wanted some more power :) and took my previous design and incorporated the 6v 3.0w bike dynamo made the blades a bit bigger, add some weight to them by putting a 6 mm filleted rod true them, this gives extra weight so the blades can turn the dynamo. Smooth the blades a bit more, the housing is the same size as the previous version, just extended the tail section.
On the test run max output measured 15v.(some parts are different on the video, pictures than the stl file, the ones uploaded are the latest version,could not reprint having some printer issues z motor controller :( ) added a ring collector to the "wind_t_h_front_V4" and reinforced it, could not test and finish because of the issue it still does the same job without the collectors.

Further on the hollow body will incorporate a charging unit and a rectifier(further research needed) to be able to use it as a usb charger, plus a universal connection for other applications.

You need:
->2 x bearings inside diameter 10 mm/26 mm outer
->6x 5x40 Machine screw and M5 nuts
->3x 5x60 Machine screw and M5 nuts
->3x 5x80 Machine screw and M5 nuts
->M10 filleted rod like 50cm
->M6 filleted rod like 3x50cm
->16mm dia. aluminium tube 3x35cm
->3x M6 nuts
->4x M10 nuts
->2x M10 washer (bigger than the bearing outer diameter use this and the rod to press the bearings into place it is quite a snug fit )
->Loctite super glue for the blades

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NPg4jT19caI
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=daZuXjDLBKo&feature=youtu.be
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KThadVf36ZU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rbjfVsfENQI

Print layer hight 0.2, PLA print. Blades and tail parts need a slow print and high fan setting also a temp of 200 C. Used 15% infill, 0.7 shell, 0.6 top/bottom on all parts, 210 C for the bigger parts !!!! when printing file (wind t h mid v2 m) you need to pause the print to put in the 3 M5 nuts in.

The upgrade V4

I'v printed all parts in PLA, the blade and cone parts at 0.2 layer hight with 0.7 shell thickness, 0.6 top/bottom thicknessprint all blade parts and the cone 3 times. Housing 0.3 ayer hight with 0.7 shell thickness 0.9 top/bottom thickness.Used 3 x 16mm aluminium tube for extending the tail section, 350mm length each.

title: Vex to stepper motor adapter hub

description.text:
*** Updated cover to r3 -- adds through hole for easier motor shaft extraction. Print without supports, because easy-breakaway supports are already in the model!

I wanted to use an old set of Vex wheels for my upcoming rover project. They use an annoying square axle, which is incompatible with standard DC motor shafts. Well, not anymore! This pair of pieces should allow me to mount the wheels to any stepper motor with a 5mm shaft. It has capture features for the M3 screws which are used to hold onto the shaft, and recesses for M4 nuts to clamp the wheel onto the hub.

Print without supports!

Uploaded r2 models to deal with some annoyances:

  • hub cover screw holes are recessed so you can use a M3x25 to clamp over the wheel. Otherwise, you'll have to go with M3x30 and have excess threads sticking out.
  • widened the captive nut slots a litle to make insertion easier.
  • added another concentric ring for support material

Press 3 M4 jam nuts into the recessed areas of the hub. Press 3 M3 jam nuts into the capture slots near where the motor shaft will go. I recommend drilling through the Vex wheel as well so you can get the hub closer to the bearings in the stepper motor.

Remove the two concentric rings under the "hub adapter M3" part. These should peel away easily due to the way I modeled them.

Screw 3 M4x25 screws into the hub to clamp down on the wheel, and then screw 3 M3 screws to hold onto the motor shaft.

Little can and bottle strainers that will protect your beverages from wasps, bees and other large insects! You may found them useful if you plan to spend some time outdoor during summer :)

This thing was not tested yet - please let me know if you have any comments!

More information about this project (in Polish):
http://3dwpraktyce.pl/2015/07/jak-chronic-napoje-przed-robalami/

Print without supports - if your printer is able to make short bridges, you shouldn't have any troubles with this thing.

Start with printing PlasticBottleBeeProtector.stl and check how it fits the plastic bottle neck. It needs to be printed very precisely, and probably it will be a bit too tight or too loose. Try to resize the STL model a bit, change printer flow rate or slicer extrusion multiplier by few percent.

Utiliser du scotch double face pour fixer le comparateur à la pièce.

For all the TF2 junkies out there like me....This is a working airsoft model of the scout's peppergun from Team Fortress 2. Works with goblin or madbull co2 shotgun shells. I would recommend putting the lightest possible bbs in the shells (probably .12's) I have one more file to upload which needs a few adjustments but then it will be fully functional and awesome.
Update
ITS DONE!!!!
the last file is now on and ready to go.
airsoft domination here you come!

With sprinkles and spice and everything nice.... Just kidding I used alot of different designs and mashed them together to make this. I didnt cite them all since some were from Grabcad. However I would specifically like to thank thecrow117 for giving me this idea. Check out his airsoft shotgun in the derivatives.
When building this there are a few things which may not fit perfectly specifically the triggers and the part which attaches to the barrel. I just used my soldering iron to fix this. Eventually, I just used a drill to bore these holes even wider and used the metal wire thingy from a binder clip to attach the barrel. The screws I used were the longest ones you can get in those erector kits but really any screw with a nut which is long enough works. Again soldering irons are your friend. Also be sure you cut your pins down so they work!

title: DJI Phantom Anti Vibration GoPro Mount

description.text: This is a radical remix of gcardinal's DJI Phantom GoPro mount. It uses cheap anti-vibration mounts from HobbyKing ($1.36) and the stock GoPro mount that came with the DJI Phantom. It took about an hour to print in ABS on my DaVinci 1.0.

Requires HobbyKing part number 017000170. Getting it all assembled can be a little frustrating so go in this order.

1-Install rubber mounts on one of the 3d printed pieces.
2- Install the 3d printed piece with the rubber mounts on to the quadcopter body using the provided DJI screws.
3- Mount the DJI GoPro mount on the other 3d printed piece using the screws and lock nuts that came with the HobbyKing rubber mount kit.
4- Carefully work the 3d printed piece with the GoPro mount on to the rubber mounts on the 3d piece connected to the body. Go slowly because this can be frustrating.
